details: “A” is the first letter and the first vowel of the modern Latin alphabet, used in English and many other languages worldwide.

wordsData.definition: a small insect that lives in a colony and has a narrow waist connecting two large sections of its body
wordsData.example: The ant carried a crumb twice its size back to its nest.

wordsData.definition: a round fruit with red, green, or yellow skin and crisp flesh
wordsData.example: She bit into a juicy red apple on a hot summer day.

wordsData.definition: a tool with a heavy bladed head mounted across a handle, used for chopping wood
wordsData.example: He swung the axe to chop the wood for the fire.

wordsData.definition: the upper limb of the human body, extending from the shoulder to the wrist
wordsData.example: He raised his arm to wave at his friend.

rhymes.name: A is for Ants (hear the tune here)
content: The ants go marching one by one, Hurrah, hurrah.
The ants go marching one by one, Hurrah, hurrah.
The ants go marching one by one,
The little one stops to suck his thumb,
And they all go marching down
To get out of the rain,

rhymes.name: A is for Apple Tree (sing to the tune of “A is for Apple Tree”)
content: Once a little apple seed was planted in the ground.
Down came the raindrops, falling all around.
Out came the big sun, bright as bright could be,
